headline: Amazon to hire 250,000 workers during holiday season for third straight year
summary: The announcement on Monday, however, comes amid concerns that U.S. shoppers will be cautious about spending in this holiday season as they brace from the impact of President Donald Trump's tariff policies.  Data firm Adobe Analytics last week projected U.S. holiday online sales to grow at a slower pace this year, but e-commerce are still expected to outshine overall sales growth.  Trump's latest tariffs on Chinese imports will have limited impact on holiday sales as most of the inventory is already in the country.

Data firm Adobe Analytics last week projected U.S. holiday online sales to grow at a slower pace this year, but e-commerce are still expected to outshine overall sales growth.  Trump's latest tariffs on Chinese imports will have limited impact on holiday sales as most of the inventory is already in the country.

headline: Factbox-From OpenAI to Meta, firms channel billions into AI infrastructure as demand booms
summary: The companies said OpenAI would design the chips, which Broadcom will develop and deploy starting in the second half of 2026.  AMD agreed to supply artificial intelligence chips to OpenAI in a multi-year deal that would also give the ChatGPT creator the option to buy up to roughly 10% of the chipmaker.  Nvidia is set to invest up to $100 billion in OpenAI and supply it with data center chips, in a deal giving the chipmaker a financial stake in OpenAI.

headline: OpenAI taps Broadcom to build its first AI processor in latest chip deal
summary: Shares of Broadcom rose more than 12% in premarket trading.  The companies said on Monday that OpenAI would design the chips, which Broadcom will develop and deploy starting in the second half of 2026.  The agreement is the latest in a string of massive AI chip investments that have highlighted the technology industry's surging appetite for computing power as it races to build systems that meet or surpass human intelligence.

headline: Veteran Stockpicker Sees Risks for AI, Big Tech. Why It Could Be Worse Than Dot-Com Bust.
summary: Rajiv Jain, chairman and chief investment officer of  GQG Partners  who rode the technology boom with stocks like  Nvidia  in recent years, is worried.  Jain, a panelist on the Barron’s Roundtable, admits he may have been early, selling Nvidia,  Alphabet  and  Amazon.com  earlier in the year and paring his stake in  Microsoft  But he says the “all-in on one-way bet on AI,” combined with decelerating growth, narrowing free cash flow margins, and increasing competition for many of the sector’s heavyweights is enough for him to move on to more defensive stocks.

raw.headline: Veteran Stockpicker Sees Risks for AI, Big Tech. Why It Could Be Worse Than Dot-Com Bust.
raw.summary: Rajiv Jain, chairman and chief investment officer of  GQG Partners  who rode the technology boom with stocks like  Nvidia  in recent years, is worried.  Jain, a panelist on the Barron’s Roundtable, admits he may have been early, selling Nvidia,  Alphabet  and  Amazon.com  earlier in the year and paring his stake in  Microsoft  But he says the “all-in on one-way bet on AI,” combined with decelerating growth, narrowing free cash flow margins, and increasing competition for many of the sector’s heavyweights is enough for him to move on to more defensive stocks.

headline: Central banks stoked the dotcom bubble. They’re doing it again for AI
summary: Blow-out quarterly earnings estimates from American software and cloud services specialist Oracle, a $100bn (£75bn) investment in ChatGPT developer OpenAI by silicon chip designer Nvidia and, in reverse, the purchase of a 10pc stake by OpenAI in another semiconductor maker, AMD, are all keeping the artificial intelligence (AI) pot boiling, so far as stock markets are concerned.

raw.headline: Central banks stoked the dotcom bubble. They’re doing it again for AI
raw.summary: Blow-out quarterly earnings estimates from American software and cloud services specialist Oracle, a $100bn (£75bn) investment in ChatGPT developer OpenAI by silicon chip designer Nvidia and, in reverse, the purchase of a 10pc stake by OpenAI in another semiconductor maker, AMD, are all keeping the artificial intelligence (AI) pot boiling, so far as stock markets are concerned.
